trustfund:
TF026845-PHRD-NICARAGUA: IMPLEMENTATION
            OF THE SUSTAINABLE FORESTRY INVESTMENT P

abstracts.cdata!:
The Sustainable Forestry Investment
            Project for Nicaragua had the following ratings: the outcome
            was unsatisfactory, the sustainability was likely, the
            institutional development impact was substantial, and the
            Bank and borrower performance were both satisfactory. The
            lessons learned indicate that in order to understand
            specific lessons from the execution of the subprojects, and
            to address the long term forestry issues in Nicaragua, the
            PCU commissioned two studies. Innovative projects should not
            necessarily reflect the prevailing Bank's strategy for
            the sector. Deforestation, inter alia, is the result of
            assigning low value to forest and forest products. Success
            in establishing sustainable forestry sector management
            requires effective and meaningful participation of
            stakeholders. Political support and Government commitment to
            a long-term goal will create confidence in the system.
            Sustainable forestry development efforts cannot succeed
            without a holistic approach that deals with land security
            and agricultural productivity. New technology transfers that
            are appropriate and divisible are not necessarily expensive.
            Assigning forests protective status might be less efficient
            unless supported by an incentive mechanism to support
            sustainable management.
